name: 1579_C. Ticks
description:
Casimir has a rectangular piece of paper with a checkered field of size n × m. Initially, all cells of the field are white.

Let us denote the cell with coordinates i vertically and j horizontally by (i, j). The upper left cell will be referred to as (1, 1) and the lower right cell as (n, m).

Casimir draws ticks of different sizes on the field. A tick of size d (d > 0) with its center in cell (i, j) is drawn as follows: 

  1. First, the center cell (i, j) is painted black. 
  2. Then exactly d cells on the top-left diagonally to the center and exactly d cells on the top-right diagonally to the center are also painted black. 
  3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for all h between 0 and d are painted. In particular, a tick consists of 2d + 1 black cells. 



An already painted cell will remain black if painted again. Below you can find an example of the 4 × 9 box, with two ticks of sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You are given a description of a checkered field of size n × m. Casimir claims that this field came about after he drew some (possibly 0) ticks on it. The ticks could be of different sizes, but the size of each tick is at least k (that is, d ≥ k for all the ticks).

Determine whether this field can indeed be obtained by drawing some (possibly none) ticks of sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.

Casimir holds a rectangular sheet with a checkered area measuring n × m. Initially, each cell within the area is white.

Let's label the cell using vertical coordinate i and horizontal coordinate j as (i, j). The cell at the top left will be labeled (1, 1), and the cell at the bottom right will be labeled (n, m).

Casimir sketches ticks of various sizes on the area. A tick of size d (d > 0) centered in cell (i, j) is created in the following manner:

1. Initially, the cell at the center (i, j) receives a black paint. 
2. Subsequently, exactly d cells in the top-left diagonal to the center and exactly d cells in the top-right diagonal to the center are also turned black. 
3. That is all the cells with coordinates (i - h, j ± h) for every h ranging from 0 to d are painted. Specifically, a tick contains a total of 2d + 1 black cells.

A cell that's already painted will remain black if repainted. Below you can see an illustration of the 4 × 9 grid, showcasing two ticks with sizes 2 and 3.

<image>

You receive a description of a checkered area sized n × m. Casimir asserts that this area resulted from him drawing several ticks on it. The ticks might vary in sizes, but each tick size is at least k (meaning d ≥ k for every tick).

Establish whether this area can actually be formed by sketching some (potentially none) ticks with sizes d ≥ k or not.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions, minimum tick size, and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a valid tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    if can_form_tick(i, j, k, n, m, grid, marked):
                        mark_tick(i, j, k, n, m, marked)

        # Verify if all '*' cells are marked
        if all(marked[i][j] or grid[i][j] == '.' for i in range(n) for j in range(m)):
            results.append('YES')
        else:
            results.append('NO')

    return results

def can_form_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, n: int, m: int, grid: List[str], marked: List[List[bool]]) -> bool:
    """Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center cell.
        j (int): Column index of the center cell.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): Grid data.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): Grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be formed, False otherwise.
    """
    for d in range(1, k + 1):
        if i - d < 0 or j - d < 0 or j + d >= m:
            return False
        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
            return False
    return True

def mark_tick(i: int, j: int, k: int, n: int, m: int, marked: List[List[bool]]) -> None:
    """Mark cells that are part of a tick of size k with (i, j) as the center.

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center cell.
        j (int): Column index of the center cell.
        k (int): Size of the tick.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        marked (List[List[bool]]): Grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick.
    """
    marked[i][j] = True
    for d in range(1, k + 1):
        marked[i - d][j - d] = True
        marked[i - d][j + d] = True

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

# Call the function and get results
results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)

# Output interface
for result in results:
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): Grid representation with '*' for painted cells and '.' for unpainted cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell is covered by a tick
        covered = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Traverse the grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if this cell can be the center of a tick of size at least k
                    size = 0
                    while (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                           grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                        size += 1

                    # If a valid tick of size k or more is found, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            covered[i - h][j - h] = True
                            covered[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Check if all '*' cells are covered by a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not covered[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions, minimum tick size, and grid data.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed with (i, j) as the center
                    can_form_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if (i - d < 0 or j - d < 0 or j + d >= m or
                            grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*'):
                            can_form_tick = False
                            break
                    if can_form_tick:
                        # Mark the cells as part of a tick
                        for d in range(k + 1):
                            marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                            marked[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Check if all '*' cells are part of a tick
        is_possible = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    is_possible = False
                    break
            if not is_possible:
                break

        results.append("YES" if is_possible else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if the grid can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_tick = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j)
                    if is_valid_tick_center(i, j, n, m, k, grid):
                        # Mark cells that can be part of a tick
                        mark_tick_cells(i, j, k, can_be_tick)

        # Check if all '*' cells can be explained by ticks
        if all(grid[i][j] == '.' or can_be_tick[i][j] for i in range(n) for j in range(m)):
            results.append('YES')
        else:
            results.append('NO')

    return results

def is_valid_tick_center(i: int, j: int, n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str]) -> bool:
    """Checks if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j).

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
        grid (List[str]): The grid representation.

    Returns:
        bool: True if a tick can be centered at (i, j), False otherwise.
    """
    for h in range(1, k + 1):
        if i - h < 0 or j - h < 0 or j + h >= m:
            return False
        if grid[i - h][j - h] != '*' or grid[i - h][j + h] != '*':
            return False
    return True

def mark_tick_cells(i: int, j: int, k: int, can_be_tick: List[List[bool]]) -> None:
    """Marks cells that can be part of a tick centered at (i, j).

    Args:
        i (int): Row index of the center.
        j (int): Column index of the center.
        k (int): Size of the tick.
        can_be_tick (List[List[bool]]): 2D list to track tick cells.
    """
    for h in range(k + 1):
        can_be_tick[i - h][j - h] = True
        can_be_tick[i - h][j + h] = True

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

# Output interface
results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
for result in results:
    print(result)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if a given grid can be formed using ticks of a specified minimum size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that are part of a valid tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size at least k can be formed
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            marked[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Verify if all '*' cells are part of a valid tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[str]:
    """Determines if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): Grid representation with '*' for black cells and '.' for white cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Check each cell to see if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(k, n):
            for j in range(k, m - k):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if the diagonals can form a tick of size k
                    valid_tick = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        if grid[i - d][j - d] != '*' or grid[i - d][j + d] != '*':
                            valid_tick = False
                            break
                    if valid_tick:
                        can_be_center[i][j] = True

        # Mark all cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if can_be_center[i][j]:
                    marked[i][j] = True
                    for d in range(1, k + 1):
                        marked[i - d][j - d] = True
                        marked[i - d][j + d] = True

        # Check if all '*' cells are marked
        all_marked = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    all_marked = False
                    break
            if not all_marked:
                break

        results.append('YES' if all_marked else 'NO')

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

import numpy as np

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: list[tuple[int, int, int, list[str]]]) -> list[str]:
    """Determine if the given grid can be formed by ticks of at least size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (list[tuple[int, int, int, list[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (list[str]): The grid representation with '*' for black cells and '.' for white cells.

    Returns:
        list[str]: List of results for each test case, "YES" if the grid can be formed by ticks, otherwise "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a numpy array for easier manipulation
        grid_array = np.array([list(row) for row in grid])
        can_form = True

        # Create a boolean array to track which cells are part of a valid tick
        valid_tick = np.full((n, m), False)

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid_array[i, j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be centered at (i, j)
                    if i >= k and j >= k and j + k < m:
                        is_valid_tick = True
                        for h in range(1, k + 1):
                            if grid_array[i - h, j - h] != '*' or grid_array[i - h, j + h] != '*':
                                is_valid_tick = False
                                break
                        if is_valid_tick:
                            # Mark the cells of this tick as valid
                            for h in range(k + 1):
                                valid_tick[i - h, j - h] = True
                                valid_tick[i - h, j + h] = True
                            valid_tick[i, j] = True

        # Check if all '*' in the grid are part of a valid tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid_array[i, j] == '*' and not valid_tick[i, j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

# Output interface
results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
for result in results:
    print(result)

## main.py
from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the grid can be formed by ticks of size at least k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a grid to mark cells that can be part of a tick
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell in the grid
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if a tick of size k can be formed centered at (i, j)
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                                grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    # If the tick size is at least k, mark the cells
                    if size > k:
                        for h in range(size):
                            marked[i - h][j - h] = True
                            marked[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Check if all '*' cells are marked
        can_form = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    can_form = False
                    break
            if not can_form:
                break

        results.append("YES" if can_form else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if each grid can be formed by drawing ticks of at least the given size.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing n, m, k, and the grid.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either "YES" or "NO".
    """
    def is_valid_tick(n: int, m: int, k: int, grid: List[str], x: int, y: int) -> bool:
        """Check if a tick of size at least k can be formed with center at (x, y).

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            k (int): Minimum size of the tick.
            grid (List[str]): The grid representation.
            x (int): Row index of the center of the tick.
            y (int): Column index of the center of the tick.

        Returns:
            bool: True if a valid tick can be formed, False otherwise.
        """
        size = 0
        while True:
            if x - size < 0 or y - size < 0 or y + size >= m:
                break
            if grid[x - size][y - size] != '*' or grid[x - size][y + size] != '*':
                break
            size += 1
        return size > k

    def mark_tick(n: int, m: int, grid: List[List[bool]], x: int, y: int, size: int):
        """Mark the cells that are part of a valid tick.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            grid (List[List[bool]]): The grid representation to mark.
            x (int): Row index of the center of the tick.
            y (int): Column index of the center of the tick.
            size (int): Size of the tick.
        """
        for i in range(size):
            grid[x - i][y - i] = True
            grid[x - i][y + i] = True

    results = []
    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        marked = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and is_valid_tick(n, m, k, grid, i, j):
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if i - size < 0 or j - size < 0 or j + size >= m:
                            break
                        if grid[i - size][j - size] != '*' or grid[i - size][j + size] != '*':
                            break
                        size += 1
                    mark_tick(n, m, marked, i, j, size)

        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not marked[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append("YES" if valid else "NO")

    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))
    # Call the function and get results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    # Output results
    for result in results:
        print(result)

## main.py
from typing import List

def can_form_ticks(t: int, test_cases: List[tuple]) -> List[str]:
    """Determine if the given grid can be formed by drawing ticks of a minimum size k.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[tuple]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - k (int): Minimum size of the ticks.
            - grid (List[str]): Grid representation with '*' for black cells and '.' for white cells.

    Returns:
        List[str]: List of results for each test case, either 'YES' or 'NO'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, k, grid in test_cases:
        # Create a 2D list to track if a cell can be part of a tick
        can_be_center = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]

        # Iterate over each cell to check if it can be the center of a tick
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*':
                    # Check if it can be the center of a tick of size at least k
                    size = 0
                    while True:
                        if (i - size >= 0 and j - size >= 0 and j + size < m and
                            grid[i - size][j - size] == '*' and grid[i - size][j + size] == '*'):
                            size += 1
                        else:
                            break

                    if size > k:
                        # Mark cells that can be part of a tick
                        for h in range(size):
                            can_be_center[i - h][j - h] = True
                            can_be_center[i - h][j + h] = True

        # Check if all '*' cells can be part of a tick
        valid = True
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '*' and not can_be_center[i][j]:
                    valid = False
                    break
            if not valid:
                break

        results.append('YES' if valid else 'NO')

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m, k = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, k, grid))

    # Call the function and print results
    results = can_form_ticks(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        print(result)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 100) — the number test cases.

The following lines contain the descriptions of the test cases. 

The first line of the test case description contains the integers n, m, and k (1 ≤ k ≤ n ≤ 10; 1 ≤ m ≤ 19) — the field size and the minimum size of the ticks that Casimir drew. The following n lines describe the field: each line consists of m characters either being '.' if the corresponding cell is not yet painted or '*' otherwise.

Output

Print t lines, each line containing the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to a test case should be YES if the given field can be obtained by drawing ticks of at least the given size and NO otherwise.

You may print every letter in any case you want (so, for example, the strings yEs, yes, Yes, and YES will all be recognized as positive answers).

Example

Input


8
2 3 1
*.*
...
4 9 2
*.*.*...*
.*.*...*.
..*.*.*..
.....*...
4 4 1
*.*.
****
.**.
....
5 5 1
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
5 5 2
.....
*...*
.*.*.
..*.*
...*.
4 7 1
*.....*
.....*.
..*.*..
...*...
3 3 1
***
***
***
3 5 1
*...*
.***.
.**..


Output


NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
NO
NO

Note

The first sample test case consists of two asterisks neither of which can be independent ticks since ticks of size 0 don't exist.

The second sample test case is already described in the statement (check the picture in the statement). This field can be obtained by drawing ticks of sizes 2 and 3, as shown in the figure.

The field in the third sample test case corresponds to three ticks of size 1. Their center cells are marked with \color{blue}{blue}, \color{red}{red} and \color{green}{green} colors: *.*.  
---  
*\color{blue}{*}**  
.\color{green}{*}\color{red}{*}.  
....  
  
The field in the fourth sample test case could have been obtained by drawing two ticks of sizes 1 and 2. Their vertices are marked below with \color{blue}{blue} and \color{red}{red} colors respectively: .....  
---  
*...*  
.*.*.  
..\color{red}{*}.*  
...\color{blue}{*}.  
  
The field in the fifth sample test case can not be obtained because k = 2, and the last asterisk in the fourth row from the top with coordinates (4, 5) can only be a part of a tick of size 1.

The field in the sixth sample test case can not be obtained because the top left asterisk (1, 1) can't be an independent tick, since the sizes of the ticks must be positive, and cannot be part of a tick with the center cell in the last row, since it is separated from it by a gap (a point, '.') in (2, 2).

In the seventh sample test case, similarly, the field can not be obtained by the described process because the asterisks with coordinates (1, 2) (second cell in the first row), (3, 1) and (3, 3) (leftmost and rightmost cells in the bottom) can not be parts of any ticks.
